BE11:18am

QUIZ’s trading in the last few months has been very
disappointing. Online sales have held up (relatively), but in-store
sales have been beyond poor. The travails at Debenhams and
HOF won’t have helped but there is a fundamental problem here
that the ranges are just not resonating with customers.
Occasionwear has been especially weak. The sales miss has bred
a margin miss as the excess stock has to be discounted. The
business is now in day-to-day losses and with little strategic
inspiration emerging with this profit warning, we can only
assume that it will be a very long road to recovery. EBITDA may
be positive next year but pre-tax losses are assured, and there
seems very little reason to hold the shares, even at the lowly
levels they will plumb today.

red all they need now is an equity busting raise and job done. everyone that counts wins.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@DJ: they can, but not while I'm also typing here.)

red if u take short cuts u step in bull$hit. avoid smalls
BE11:19am

The problems at Debs and House of Fraser are clearly worth noting here, but not worth overemphasising. The problems in this business run much deeper.

Soundbuy 'special occasion womenswear'...........surely a ltd mkt full-stop........
BE11:20am

What is going wrong? Sales trends had been erratic in H1 but in H2 they have been disappointingly consistent in their weakness and it now appears that the ranges are not cutting it with shoppers. QUIZ has always been a business that was close to its customers and engagement on social media is high but the latest ranges have not drawn people into the stores. That online sales are robust (although growing much slower than they were) is at least some solace but at a time when we think the general UK consumer is on a more even keel than it was before Christmas, this without doubt is a QUIZ-specific problem.
What’s the answer? Clearly improving the range is a must but brands can lose their credibility and recovery from there is often tough. The average lease length is very short, so the tail of underperforming stores can be cut quickly. However, management doesn’t seem to have any answers in the short term and it’s hard to see sales growth returning any time soon. The overseas expansion plan now looks like a diversion that management doesn’t need. The divi will obviously go.
EBITDA estimates go from £8.2m to £4.5m this year, £7.6m to £1.3m next.
Hard to be positive. There’s always a temptation to try to catch a falling knife but not in this instance. Until management can come up with a coherent plan to turn the situation around, the shares are going to find it hard to stabilise. 4x FY21 EBITDA would feel generous but would mean an EV and mkt cap of £15m and a TP of 12p. The shares are not worth bottom fishing for. SELL

Goldman:

11:26 am
BE11:26am

We view the results as positive given the strong operating performance across all the segments. We also see management’s reiteration of 2019 guidance as a positive. In our view, the company has addressed major investor concerns: (i) organic growth was 15% in 2018 and guidance is now for 12%-13% in 2019, (ii) the completion of JV with Hassana improves its presence in the Saudi market, which is a key regional market for the company; (iii) the company is focused on improving working capital, primarily receivables, which increased in 1H18. However, we note that NMC’s net income growth lagged EBITDA growth and this could weigh on the stock in the near term as financial costs were ahead of expectation.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian This from the FT: "Melrose is a listed turnround specialist that buys underperforming engineering or manufacturing businesses with the goal of increasing profitability before selling them on."Underperforming according to who? Melrose propaganda blurb and short-termists.
BE11:27am

And Citi.

BE11:27am

NMC reported sales growth of 28% to $2057m (Cons $2000m,
guidance +24%), EBITDA growth of 37.9% to $487m (cons $476m, guidance
$480m), and diluted adjusted EPS of $1.33 (+20%) below cons of $1.40. Despite
beats on sales and EBITDA, NMC reported higher-than-expected depreciation and
net interest charges of $115m (this is partly due to the convertible, and cash flow
net finance charges of ~$87m were in-line with our forecasts), which dragged on
earnings. Proposed DPS of $0.181 is below cons of $0.25. H2 performance was
sales/EBITDA growth. +36/43% Y/Y and +21/16% H/H. Organic sales growth was
+15.4% vs. guidance of 15%, with Abu Dhabi Specialty +8.1% Y/Y, Al Zahra 13.0%
Y/Y and Royal +30.3% Y/Y.
 Solid progress on cash flow – Receivables investments absorbed only $44m of
cash flow from operations, significantly better than FY ‘17a ($82m) and CitiE
($128m), for receivables days of 96 (down from 107 at H1). NWC/sales was 27.7%
(FY ‘17a: 30.6%). EBITDA cash conversion post-working capital was 80% (100%
conversion pre-working capital). Capex was $165m, split b/w $101m growth capex
and $64m maintenance. We calculate FCF to shareholders at $134m as reported,
or $235m when adjusting for growth capex.
 Corporate action slows in H2 – NMC spent $553m on M&A in the period, most
notably on stakes in CosmeSurge, Fakih IVF, and the newly announced Boston IVF
($65m / ~1x sales). We think the market could be encouraged by a slowed pace of
M&A in H2. We took a positive view on the definitive terms agreed with GOSI (see
supports our positive view). ND/EBITDA stood at 3.1x in-line with guide of 3.0x (pro
forma 3.0x too). EBITDA/net interest coverage remained comfortable at 3.2x.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Implications — NMC bears will point to the EPS/dividend miss, but we are
encouraged by the results given sales/EBITDA beats, organic growth, a better cash
flow performance, slower pace of M&A, and unchanged 2019 guidance: Sales +22-
24% and EBITDA +18-20%, ND/EBITDA 2.2-2.4x; excl. IFRS 16 and Care.

A. M. @FletcherChristian: All true, I guess it's not acceptable to say "so-and-so are asset strippers"
BE11:28am

Barclays .....

FATDAZ @RW42 same here
BE11:28am

NMC Health reported its full year results for FY18 this morning, which surprised us positively on underlying operations (fear #1). We raise our 19E-21E sales estimates by 1.2%-1.4% and EBITDA by 1.8%-2.4% and note management’s confidence in the re-iterated2019 outlook, which we expect to be raised when more detail is provided on CARE in the coming weeks. The company saw a normalization of receivables (fear #2) to 96 days in FY 2018, compared to 107in H1 2018 and 100 in 2017. We discussed this in detail in our recent forensic accounting report (see: Healthier than you think, 4 March2019), in conjunction with our accounting team, which we update here. We increase our eFCF estimates by 3.1% in FY19E, and note that a higher level of growth capex in 2018E drove a slightly weaker level of eFCF in 2018 relative to our expectations. The CARE JV closed on Tuesday (fear #3, see: Saudi JV closes, 5 March2019), which we consider to be a positive development and look forward to further detail here in due course. With sentiment subdued on the stock based on our recent discussions with investors as well as a 9% short base, we expect these results to be taken well by the market.

Here's Goldman.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Melrose has delivered reassuring results, with 2018 adjusted operating profit on a fully consolidated basis coming in slightly ahead of consensus (2% beat, 12% beat including IFRS adjustments for loss making contracts) and net debt/ebitda slightly better than expected at 2.3x (guidance 2.5x). Melrose has solid foundations to meet current 2019 consensus, in our view. In Aerospace, loss-making US aerostructures, which was responsible for the profit warnings in 2017, finished 2018 at a break even run-rate. In Driveline, management believes operating margin can still be improved in 2019, despite some evidence of a slowdown. There is no news on the Powder Metallurgy disposal, but significant margin potential still exists. We expect more colour later.

BE11:38am

Brief divisional margin colour: Aerospace delivered a 9.6% annualised 2018
nadjusted operating margin broken down by Aerospace other (10.1%), US Aerostructures (-1.0%). Driveline delivered a 7.3% annualised 2018 adjusted operating margin broken down by Driveline 8.0%, China 12.9%, All Wheel Drive 7.3% and eDrive which made a £54m loss.

wayneJ Question: Under IFRS do future 'management payments' to private equity owners have to be disclosed as a (contingent) liability on the balance sheet - just asking for a friend?
BE11:38am

Solid FCF generation: FCF of £196m was better than our expectations (nil)
ndriven by higher operating cash flow due to less working capital consumption, lower cash exceptional items and lower other items such as interest. Net debt was still higher than consensus expectations as it has FX movements, it was higher than stated when acquired due to trading movements and a £129m payment of GKN defence costs. However, leverage of 2.3x was better than expected (2.5x). Melrose’s existing undrawn borrowing facilities (RCF) offer £1.35bn liquidity.

Grouchmonkey @excel think this is an excellent trend. It's like tohe original's of surnames like "painter" "carpenter" etc. Bryce Alphaville has a ring to it.

BE11:39am

BE11:39am

Divisional trading and outlook. Aerospace had a stronger than
expected performance in 2018 helped by the supportive market and
improvement at the North America Aerostructures business to close to
break-even by the year-end. Further progress in both sales and margins is
expected in 2019. The market backdrop in Automotive has weakened
albeit the business finished the year ahead of expectations. We expect a
top-line decline in 2019 but not currently a major impact on profits.
Power Metallurgy performed well albeit with some signs of slowing in
automotive markets. Management has reiterated the 14% margin target.
Nortek saw flat underlying sales and a flat margin with a mixed
performance across the businesses and some impact from tariffs; we
expect a return to growth in 2019.
Capital Markets Day. The Capital Markets Day will be held on 3 April
in London. The event will focus on the Aerospace and Automotive
businesses and we expect to hear from the heads of the two divisions on
the opportunities to improve profitability. We expect management to
announce long-term margin targets for both the Aerospace and
Automotive divisions and do not expect the size of the improvement to
disappoint the market.

Excel Developer #ECB: Is it TLTROs day, or is it prepare next meeting for TLTROs day?
BE11:48am

Dividend: Commitment to the current dividend (+1% vs. consensus) and
nmovement to a progressive dividend going forward (versus a pay-out ratio previously). In this context, management has stated that future percentage growth rates of the dividend per share will be more modest than those in the recent past.

red @FATDAZumicore does the batteries and the recycling. its a buy on dips. when crap stuff happens and goes down a fair bit, buy those dips imo
Excel Developer #ECB new staff macro -econ projections today.
Grouchmonkey @fatdaz good point.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

Balance Sheet: Debt reduction of £1.5bn by 2021/2022, which is expected to
ngive a pro-forma leverage ratio of 29% (vs. 33% currently). This will have a mechanical impact on Solvency II coverage, however, we note that after strong capital generation and modelling impacts (from the roll-out of DVA in France, Poland and the UK) in 2H18, the group is unlikely to move outside of its (revised) target range 160% to 180%.

FATDAZ @excel HSBC said wait until April
red @Excel Developerthe latter or euro will tank.
BE11:49am

Earnings Growth: EPS momentum in 2019 alone may be tempered from the
nhistorical 7% growth due to tax changes, evolving business mix, lower opening balances (following recent adverse market movements) and the impact of potential disposals (per Aviva, Friends Provident International).
GS view: Overall, we see this as a strong set of results. The key messages around the dividend security and balance sheet restoration (notably de-leveraging) should be taken as a significant positive. Today’s dividend announcement (30 pence per share) equates to trailing yield of 7.0% which is the highest ordinary yield of any European multi-line insurer. This yield should also grow in-line with the group’s operating performance, but is a progressive dividend meaning downside risk is removed. While there are some one-off headwinds to 2019 earnings growth, given weak capital markets in late-2018, we expect investors to focus on the favourable messages on both dividend and balance sheet progression.

FATDAZ @red thanks useful to know

And Barclays.

Flaneur @WayneJ - this is true but my information is that EVs with self-drive/assistance systems are far more efficient and have noticably reduced tyre-wear than normal 'person' driving. (less hard stopping and starting for example)
wayneJ The problem with entering the battery business is scale. I don't think the UK (investor) market has the appetite for the size of investment required to build a giga factory.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Aviva reported operating earnings of £3,116m, 1% ahead of consensus of £3,095m (Barclays £3,009m), with life insurance (4% ahead) and general insurance (2% ahead) both ahead, offset by lower asset management (6% miss) and higher group central costs (14% ahead). The beat was primarily driven by higher longevity releases in UK life, with UK management actions £350m (£90m higher YoY). The company is increasing the dividend by 9% to 30.0p, in line with consensus and equivalent to a 6.9% yield. The company has changed the dividend policy to a progressive policy, focusing on maintaining the dividend or growing over time “depending on business performance and growth prospects”, moving away from a payout ratio (50 to 60%). The company has also indicated that it will focus its capital deployment on reducing debt (by at least £1.5bn) by the end of 2022, saving £90m in interest expenses and lowering debt leverage. This would add c1% to earnings growth in each of the next three years.

As we said in our November 2018 note “EPS not DPS cuts required”, we did expect a rebasing down of EPS and forward DPS growth, but we did not expect the dividend itself to be cut, and today’s results are in line with that view. That said, the magnitude of negative EPS revisions is likely to be larger than we expected (not going from mid single digit to low single growth, but a rebasing lower of 2019 EPS). The CFO has effectively warned on 2019 EPS, saying in his outlook statement “Given current uncertainties, including the unknown future impacts of Brexit on the economies of the United Kingdom and Europe, our near-term outlook entering 2019 is more muted than our outlook a year ago. While we achieved 7% operating EPS, growth in each of the past two years, it will be difficult to sustain this momentum in 2019.”

wayneJ @Flaneur - that is really interesting
A. M. (@Flaneur: also because sometimes they don't stop..)
BE11:50am

In our note last week (1 March 2019) “Radical change to add value”, we argued that the next CEO of Aviva, whoever that might be, needed to enact radical change in order to unlock value in Aviva and to be ceased to be viewed as a value trap. While an external candidate was much more likely to go down this path, we would not rule out Maurice Tulloch also releasing value, and in the outlook statement, the company has left the door open to asset disposals, stating “Our challenge is to capitalise on these strengths to become a better, simpler, more efficient company known for excellence in serving customers. This will require significant improvements by Aviva. It will also entail choices with respect to resource allocation.”

Flaneur @AM - lol - thats another discussion....

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Previously guidance was for the payout ratio to expand to be in the range of 55-
60% by 2020 - the payout ratio for FY18 was 51.4%.
Looking at Bloomberg consensus, the market expects 7.0% EPS growth in FY19
and 4.5% growth in FY20 - with the implied payout ratio in each year being 53%
and 57% respectively. For FY21 - earnings expectations flatten, but the dividend
payout expected is ~58%. If we assume 3% p.a. EPS growth (roughly in-line with
the organic EPS growth in FY18) over FY19 and FY20 this would suggest a FY20
EPS of 61.95p (5.3% downgrade for cons) and then the applying the FY18 payout
ratio of 51.4% would give a FY20 DPS of 31.84p (14.1% downgrade).
We believe that this could be a 'worst case' assessment as the progressive
dividend policy will see "the dividend maintained or grown over time depending
on the business performance and growth". However, decomposing the 7% EPS
growth for FY18, just under half of this is organic while the rest is from the
buyback, debt reduction and assumption changes. It is likely we believe the
market settles for a low single digit EPS outlook.

We are willing to consider that zero industrial FCF is not a sustainable level but the stock is not reflecting that as a run rate with an $85 B market cap. The answer to us is somewhere in between where the stock is today and zero and that is where generally our PT sits. Much Buy-rated sell side analysis still seems to us to be built on a notion that things can V-shape hard in 2020/2021 off of a high base of FCF – contrary to what the CEO said. If it is indeed modest negative FCF, we estimate this would mean enterprise FCF of -$4.5 B, which would suggest that soon after the $1 anchor became +$0.50 as we had shown in prior research, the +$0.50 has now become close to NEGATIVE $0.50.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

We disagree with the view that it’s “not that bad”, and while “cutting numbers, reiterating Buy” is fairly common for the sell side, we reject this approach of cut and push to the next year, which has been going on for almost two decades now for some. Unlike prior episodes that were based on next year, this seems to stretch into 2021, a whole new level. As long as this sentiment prevails, we don’t think the stock can bottom. Our PT remains $6 and looks generous after today’s news.

BE12:04pm

Decent FY 2018 results with a wide guidance range, though core Fleet Broadband product saw its worst-ever quarter. 4Q Revenue 3.2% ahead due to Government revenue, and 4Q EBITDA 10.7% ahead due to Aviation. Maiden 2019 Revenue Guidance of $1.3bn - $1.4bn compares to consensus for 2019 of $1,374m, so range is -5% below to +2% above with the mid point -1.7% below.

A lot of focus is likely to be on Maritime market share. Inmarsat data implies it has c.72% market share (being 32.6k FleetBroadband/ 45k total) in “middle market “. Inmarsat says the middle market (ie, total market) is likely to decline from c.45k ships to c.25k ships by 2023. If we assume a static 72% market share, this implies Inmarsat will have c.18k FBB ships by 2023. This is substantially below our estimates – we have c.25k by 2023. Our numbers assume a c.-5% CAGR decline in FleetBroadband to 2023. Inmarsat’s comments imply an -11% CAGR decline. Against these ship losses, Inmarsat is gaining a large number of ships migrating up to its higher-speed VSAT services. Inmarsat says it took 50% of global market share of these in 2018. However, since Inmarsat currently has c.72% market share, this implies significant market loss from those migrating.

Aviation is decent with In-Flight Connectivity (IFC) revenues now c. $101m, with .1,580 aircraft under contract, with an additional c.450 committed or optioned aircraft. 452 GX and EAN aircraft now installed for IFC (FY 2017: 194) with 100+ aircraft now in commercial service on GX.

BE12:10pm

FY18 results report year-end AUM at £407.2bn vs our £416.4bn and operating profit was reported at £760.2m vs our £761.9m. We think the market will pay attention to the higher than expected institutional outflow, but we note that this was concentrated in one low margin mandate. We like SDR's scale and diversity and rate the shares a Buy.

BE12:10pm

Net outflow of £9.5bn and negative investment returns of £19.6bn took AUM to £407.2bn, below our £416.4bn estimate. Q4 market movements had a significant impact on investment performance and flows, but outflows were generally from lower margin business, including redemptions from Australian pension funds and one significant client in Japan (c.£5bn of the £6.6bn), although North American, c.£3bn net inflow, demand for equity mandates and UK demand for multi-asset solutions partially offset that. Sentiment sales "turned sharply negative" in Q4, leading to outflows in DM equities. Wealth and Private Assets saw positive flows of £1.7bn and c. £2.3bn respectively.

BE12:10pm

The overall fee margin was stable at 47bps and group PBT was in line with our forecasts at £761.2m (JEFe £761.9m). Exceptional costs of £56m relating to investments in structural change in the group contributed to a PBT reduction from £760.2m in 2017 to £649.9m. This charge will help keep the compensation ratio stable in future, and we expect to hear more about it in the presentation later this morning. Adjusted PBT and EPS were in line with forecasts and the dividend was 1p higher at 114p.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

The main AUM impact was in Q4, and we only expect a modest impact in 2019 due to the low-margin nature of the main institutional redemptions. Of the £85bn notified inflows, we know that c. £80bn is from the announced SWIP deal, so SDR has visibility of a further £5bn. The outlook statement notes industry headwinds, but we would agree that SDR's diversity and scale position it well for future long-term growth.
